answers.answer: Your father's condition is not unusual. It is more common in light complected, fair colored eyes (blue, gray, green). Also in those with large pupils. Over the years as a cataract develops it turns the clear lens of the eye into a yellow-brown marble. This cuts down the light falling on the retina (like an internal pair of sunglasses) and washes out color especially blue.After surgery much more light gets to the retina through the clear implant and glare (photophobia) is a problem for some, to others things look "too blue" for a while.Abnormal things within the eye that might cause this include cloudy membrane behind the IOL (why he had Yag capsulotomy, decentered IOL, inflammation within the eye, some macular problems. A good eye exam by a Eye MD (ophthalmologist) should exclude these.While this generally get better with times it remains a problem for others. Things that can be done to help the problem include a hat with a brim outdoors, sun glasses or sun goggles that go over regular glasses and wrap over the top and around the side of regular glasses or transition glasses that darken and lighten.I am less inclided to blame the diabetes and blood surgal levels.JCH MD Eye Physician & Surgeon    (ophthalmologist = Eye MD)

question: My father has undergone Cataract surgery - Phaco method and has had IOL's put in.   While his vision seems to have improved post the surgery,  he has developed a sensitivity to light.   Going out during day time is a problem.   He needs to squint to maintain clear vision even indoors.   Was adviced by the surgeon that this could be due to a genetic disorder in certain cases where in capsulation develops behind the IOL's leading to this glare.He was further adviced to undergo Yag laser to treat the situation and was given 3 exposures of 3 kj for each eye.   The glare has not mitigated and during check up with the surgeon,  he expressed that it could be due to his inherent diabeties condition and that there are pigments found which contribute to the glare.   He has adviced my father to regulate his sugar levels and keep them under check to control this problem.Would like to understand more about this condition and ensure all possible issues have been addressed.  Kindly help.
title: Post operative glare- catract
